course.description_en: Build essential reading skills through systematic phonics instruction, sight word recognition, and comprehension activities. Students will learn to decode simple words, read basic sentences, and understand what they read. This foundational course prepares children for independent reading success through engaging stories, hands-on activities, and progressive skill building.

course.subject: language_arts

content_data.title: Connecting Letters to Their Sounds
content_data.content: Every letter has a special sound! When we see a letter, we can say its sound. This helps us read words. Let's practice with some letters you know. The letter 'A' says /a/ like in 'apple' and 'ant.' The letter 'B' says /b/ like in 'ball' and 'bat.' The letter 'C' says /k/ like in 'cat' and 'cup.' When we put letters together, their sounds blend to make words. Let's try: C-A-T. Say each sound slowly: /k/ /a/ /t/. Now say them faster: cat! You just read a word by blending letter sounds. This is called phonics, and it's the key to reading any word.
learning_objectives: Associate letters with their corresponding sounds
Practice blending individual letter sounds into words
Understand that letters combine to form meaningful words
Develop phonemic awareness through sound manipulation

vocabulary_words.definition: The way letters and sounds work together to make words
Put sounds together smoothly to make a word
The noise a letter makes when you say it
Figure out what a word says by using letter sounds

materials_needed: Objects that start with target letters
content_data.parent_guidance: Help child feel their mouth and throat as they make different sounds. Emphasize that every letter has a job - to make a sound. Practice blending slowly at first, then gradually speed up. Celebrate when child successfully blends a word.
safety_notes: Use large, clear letter cards appropriate for age
Ensure pencils have erasers and are not too sharp
Keep small objects away from mouth during sound practice
Maintain good posture during reading activities
reading_practice_suggestions: Practice letter sounds: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J
Blend simple CVC words: cat, bat, hat, sit, pit, hit
Read letter combinations: at, it, an, in
Identify beginning sounds in familiar words
assessment_components: Can child produce correct sound for each letter?
Can child blend three sounds to make a word?
Does child understand that letters represent sounds?
Can child identify beginning sounds in words?
discussion_questions: What sound does the letter B make?
Can you blend these sounds: C-A-T?

content_data.title: Learning Word Patterns and Families
content_data.content: Some words are like family members - they look alike and sound alike! Word families share the same ending sounds and letters. Let's explore the '-at' family: cat, bat, hat, mat, rat, sat. Notice how they all end the same way? Just change the first letter and you get a new word! The '-an' family includes: can, man, pan, ran, tan, van. The '-it' family has: bit, fit, hit, kit, pit, sit. When you know one word in a family, you can read all the others! This makes reading much easier because patterns repeat in many words.
learning_objectives: Recognize common word family patterns (-at, -an, -it, -og, -ug)
Generate new words by changing initial consonants
Understand that word families share spelling and sound patterns
Build reading fluency through pattern recognition

vocabulary_words.definition: Words that end with the same letters and sounds
Something that repeats in the same way
Words that sound the same at the end
Letters that are not vowels (A, E, I, O, U)

content_data.parent_guidance: Start with one word family and help child see the pattern. Use magnetic letters to build words by changing just the first letter. Read the word family words in a rhythmic, chant-like way to emphasize the rhyming pattern.
safety_notes: Ensure magnetic letters are large enough to handle safely
Use washable markers on whiteboard
Keep workspace organized to prevent tripping
Supervise use of small letter manipulatives
reading_practice_suggestions: Read -at family: cat, bat, hat, mat, rat, sat, fat, pat
Read -an family: can, man, pan, ran, tan, van, fan
Read -it family: bit, fit, hit, kit, pit, sit, wit
Practice changing first letters to make new words
assessment_components: Can child read at least 4 words from each word family?

Does child recognize the pattern in word families?
Can child predict what a new word family word might be?
discussion_questions: What do all the -at words have in common?

content_data.title: Recognizing Common Words Instantly
content_data.content: Some words appear so often in books that we need to recognize them instantly - these are sight words! Words like 'the,' 'and,' 'is,' 'you,' 'to,' 'a,' 'I,' 'it,' 'in,' and 'was' show up in almost every sentence. Some sight words follow phonics rules, but others are tricky and need to be memorized. For example, 'the' doesn't sound like t-h-e if you try to sound it out! We'll practice these important words until you can read them as quickly as you can say your name. Knowing sight words makes reading much easier and faster.
learning_objectives: Instantly recognize the first 20 high-frequency sight words
Understand the difference between decodable and sight words
Read sight words in the context of simple sentences
Build automatic word recognition for reading fluency

vocabulary_words.definition: Common words we should recognize instantly without sounding out
Words that appear very often in books and writing
Right away, without having to think about it
Learn something so well you remember it perfectly

content_data.parent_guidance: Practice sight words daily for short periods. Focus on 3-5 words at a time until child masters them, then add new ones. Use the words in sentences and point them out in books. Make it fun with games rather than drilling.
safety_notes: Keep flash card sessions short to prevent eye strain
Use appropriate lighting for reading activities
Take breaks if child shows signs of frustration
Ensure cards are sturdy and won't cause paper cuts
reading_practice_suggestions: Practice sight words: the, and, is, you, to, a, I, it, in, was
Read sentences: 'I can see the cat.' 'You and I go to bed.'
Find sight words in simple books
Speed practice: How fast can you read these words?
assessment_components: Can child read sight words within 3 seconds each?
Does child recognize sight words in context of sentences?

content_data.title: From Simple to Complex Word Structures
content_data.content: Now that you can read simple three-letter words, let's build bigger ones! We can add letters to the beginning (blends like 'st,' 'br,' 'cl') or to the end (like adding 's' or 'ing'). For example: 'cat' becomes 'cats' or 'sitting.' We can also learn about silent letters that don't make sounds, like the 'e' at the end of 'cake' and 'bike.' This silent 'e' actually changes how the vowel sounds! Compare 'cap' and 'cape,' or 'bit' and 'bite.' Learning these patterns helps you read thousands of new words!
learning_objectives: Recognize and read consonant blends (st, br, cl, tr, etc.)
Understand the silent 'e' rule and its effect on vowel sounds
Read words with common endings (-s, -ing, -ed)
Apply knowledge of word parts to decode unfamiliar words

vocabulary_words.definition: Two consonants that work together but keep their sounds
A letter in a word that doesn't make any sound
The letters A, E, I, O, U that make the main sounds in words
Letters added to the end of a word to change its meaning

content_data.parent_guidance: Build words step by step, showing how adding letters changes the word. Use manipulatives to physically show the word building process. Emphasize the magic of silent 'e' by contrasting word pairs. Practice one concept at a time.
safety_notes: Use large letter manipulatives appropriate for age
Organize materials to prevent loss of small pieces
Ensure adequate workspace for building activities
Take breaks to prevent frustration with complex concepts
reading_practice_suggestions: Read blend words: stop, blue, clap, tree, frog, snow
Practice silent 'e' words: cake, bike, rope, cute, wide
Read words with endings: cats, running, jumped, cars
Compare short and long vowel words: hop/hope, bit/bite
assessment_components: Can child read consonant blend words accurately?
Does child understand how silent 'e' changes vowel sounds?
Can child read words with common endings?
Is child applying word building knowledge to new words?
discussion_questions: What happens when we add 'e' to the end of 'cap'?
How do you read the 'st' in 'stop'?

content_data.title: Putting Words Together to Make Meaning
content_data.content: Now it's time to read whole sentences! A sentence is a group of words that tells us something complete. Every sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period. Let's start with simple sentences using words you know: 'The cat is big.' 'I can run fast.' 'You and I are friends.' When you read a sentence, think about what it's telling you. Does it make sense? Can you picture it in your mind? Good readers always think about what they're reading, not just say the words.
learning_objectives: Read simple sentences with 4-6 words accurately
Understand that sentences convey complete thoughts
Recognize sentence structure (capital letter, period)
Demonstrate basic reading comprehension by explaining what was read

vocabulary_words.definition: A group of words that tells a complete thought
A big letter that starts sentences and names
The dot that shows a sentence is finished
Understanding what you read, not just saying words

content_data.parent_guidance: Read sentences together, pointing to each word. Ask 'What did that sentence tell us?' after reading. If child struggles with a word, help them sound it out or provide the word and keep reading. Focus on meaning, not perfection.
safety_notes: Use books with large, clear print
Ensure good lighting for reading
Encourage good posture while reading
Take breaks if child shows eye strain or fatigue
reading_practice_suggestions: Read sentences: 'The dog can run.' 'I like to play.' 'We go to bed.'
Practice with picture support: Match sentences to pictures
Read predictable sentences: 'I can see a ___.'
Answer questions: 'Who can run?' 'What do you like to do?'
assessment_components: Can child read simple sentences smoothly?
Does child pause appropriately at periods?
Can child explain what a sentence was about?
Is child using picture clues to support reading?
discussion_questions: What did this sentence tell you?

content_data.title: Understanding How Stories Work
content_data.content: Every story has three important parts: beginning, middle, and end. The beginning tells us who the story is about and where it happens. The middle tells us what happens - this is usually the exciting part! The end tells us how everything turns out. Let's read a simple story together: 'Tom the cat was hungry. He looked for food everywhere. He found a bowl of milk and was happy.' Can you find the beginning? (Tom was hungry) The middle? (He looked for food) The end? (He found milk and was happy) Understanding story parts helps us remember what we read.
learning_objectives: Identify beginning, middle, and end of simple stories
Understand basic story structure and sequence
Retell stories using proper sequence
Connect story events to build comprehension

vocabulary_words.definition: The start of a story that introduces characters and setting

content_data.parent_guidance: Read stories together and discuss each part. Ask 'What happened first? Then what? How did it end?' Help child identify the main character and setting. Encourage retelling in their own words.
safety_notes: Choose age-appropriate books with simple plots

discussion_questions: Who is the main character in this story?

content_data.title: Connecting Reading and Writing Skills
content_data.content: Reading and writing work together like best friends! When you can read a word, you can also learn to write it. We'll start by tracing letters and words, then copying them, and finally writing them from memory. Remember to start at the top for most letters and use proper spacing between words. Writing helps you understand how words work and makes you a better reader. Let's practice writing some of the words you've learned to read: cat, and, the, big, run. Take your time and make each letter carefully.
learning_objectives: Form letters correctly using proper starting points and direction
Copy simple words accurately with appropriate spacing
Write familiar words from memory
Understand the connection between reading and writing

vocabulary_words.definition: Follow over letters that are already written

content_data.parent_guidance: Help child hold pencil correctly and start letters at the right place. Encourage proper posture and paper position. Praise effort over perfection. If child gets frustrated, take a break and try again later.
safety_notes: Use pencils with good erasers, not too sharp
Ensure proper lighting for writing activities
Encourage breaks to prevent hand fatigue
Use age-appropriate pencil thickness

content_data.title: Celebrating Reading Progress and Skills
content_data.content: It's time to see how much you've learned! This isn't a test - it's a celebration of your reading skills. We'll play some fun games to show off what you can do. You'll read some words, read a short sentence, and tell me about a simple story. Remember, every reader learns at their own pace, and you should be proud of how far you've come. Reading is like building with blocks - each new skill you learn makes you stronger!
learning_objectives: Demonstrate mastery of taught phonics patterns and sight words
Read simple sentences with fluency and comprehension
Show understanding of story structure and sequence
Build confidence in reading abilities and progress

vocabulary_words.definition: A fun way to show what you have learned

content_data.parent_guidance: Keep assessment positive and encouraging. If child struggles with something, make a note to practice it more. Celebrate successes enthusiastically. Use results to guide future learning, not to judge child's abilities.
safety_notes: Keep assessment pressure-free and positive
Allow child to take breaks if needed
Focus on effort and progress, not perfection
Stop if child becomes frustrated or tired

Demonstrate comprehension: Answer questions about what was read

content_data.title: Putting All Skills Together with Real Books
content_data.content: Now you're ready to read real books! We'll start with books that have lots of pictures and simple words you know. These are called 'beginning reader books' or 'easy readers.' When you come to a word you don't know, try these strategies: look at the picture for clues, sound out the word using phonics, or think about what would make sense in the sentence. Remember, all readers - even grown-ups - sometimes come across words they don't know. The important thing is to keep trying and enjoy the story!
learning_objectives: Apply all learned reading skills to read connected text
Use multiple strategies when encountering unknown words
Read with expression and appropriate pacing
Develop independence and confidence as a reader

vocabulary_words.definition: A helpful way to figure out something difficult

materials_needed: Beginning reader books at appropriate level
content_data.parent_guidance: Choose books slightly below child's frustration level for confidence building. Read together, taking turns with pages or sentences. Don't correct every mistake - focus on meaning and enjoyment. Celebrate reading milestones.
safety_notes: Provide good lighting for reading

Choose books with sturdy binding
Maintain comfortable reading position

content_data.title: Celebrating Your Reading Journey
content_data.content: Congratulations! You are now a reader! Think about your amazing journey: you learned that letters make sounds, sounds blend into words, words combine into sentences, and sentences tell stories. You can read sight words instantly, decode new words using phonics, and understand what you read. You know that stories have beginnings, middles, and ends. You can even write some of the words you read! Reading opens up a whole world of adventures, information, and imagination. Every book you read makes you a stronger reader. Keep practicing, keep exploring, and most importantly, keep enjoying the wonderful world of reading!
learning_objectives: Reflect on reading skills acquired throughout the course
Demonstrate confidence and enthusiasm for reading
